column2: CHAPTER III
column3: CHAPTER three

column2: THE ENCHANTED STAG
column3: THE ENCHANTED STAG

column2: There were once a brother and sister who loved each other dearly; their mother was dead, and their father had married again a woman who was most unkind and cruel to them.
column3: There were once a brother and sister who loved each other dearly; their mother was dead, and their father had married again a woman who was most unkind and cruel to them.

column2: One day the boy took his sister's hand, and said to her, "Dear little sister, since our mother died we have not had one happy hour.
column3: One day the boy took his sister's hand, and said to her, "Dear little sister, since our mother died we have not had one happy hour.

column2: Our stepmother gives us dry hard crusts for dinner and supper; she often knocks us about, and threatens to kick us out of the house.
column3: Our stepmother gives us dry hard crusts for dinner and supper; she often knocks us about, and threatens to kick us out of the house.

column2: Even the little dogs under the table fare better than we do, for she often throws them nice pieces to eat.
column3: Even the little dogs under the table fare better than we do, for she often throws them nice pieces to eat.

column2: Heaven pity us!
column3: Heaven pity us!

column2: Oh, if our dear mother knew!
column3: Oh, if our dear mother knew!

column2: Come, let us go out into the wide world!"
column3: Come, let us go out into the wide world!"

column2: So they went out, and wandered over fields and meadows the whole day till evening.
column3: So they went out, and wandered over fields and meadows the whole day till evening.

column2: At last they found themselves in a large forest; it began to rain, and the little sister said, "See, brother, heaven and our hearts weep together." At last, tired out with hunger and sorrow, and the long journey, they crept into a hollow tree, laid themselves down, and slept till morning.
column3: At last they found themselves in a large forest; it began to rain, and the little sister said, "See, brother, heaven and our hearts weep together." At last, tired out with hunger and sorrow, and the long journey, they crept into a hollow tree, laid themselves down, and slept till morning.

column2: When they awoke the sun was high in the heavens, and shone brightly into the hollow tree, so they left their place of shelter and wandered away in search of water.
column3: When they awoke the sun was high in the heavens, and shone brightly into the hollow tree, so they left their place of shelter and wandered away in search of water.

column2: Oh, I am so thirsty! said the boy.
column3: Oh, I am so thirsty! said the boy.

column2: If we could only find a brook or a stream. He stopped to listen, and said, "Stay, I think I hear a running stream." So he took his sister by the hand, and they ran together to find it.
column3: If we could only find a brook or a stream. He stopped to listen, and said, "Stay, I think I hear a running stream." So he took his sister by the hand, and they ran together to find it.

column2: Now, the stepmother of these poor children was a wicked witch.
column3: Now, the stepmother of these poor children was a wicked witch.

column2: She had seen the children go away, and, following them cautiously like a snake, had bewitched all the springs and streams in the forest.
column3: She had seen the children go away, and, following them cautiously like a snake, had bewitched all the springs and streams in the forest.

column2: The pleasant trickling of a brook over the pebbles was heard by the children as they reached it, and the boy was just stooping to drink, when the sister heard in the babbling of the brook:
column3: The pleasant trickling of a brook over the pebbles was heard by the children as they reached it, and the boy was just stooping to drink, when the sister heard in the babbling of the brook:

column2: Whoever drinks of me, a tiger soon will be.
column3: Whoever drinks of me, a tiger soon will be.

column2: Then she cried quickly, "Stay, brother, stay! do not drink, or you will become a wild beast, and tear me to pieces."
column3: Then she cried quickly, "Stay, brother, stay! do not drink, or you will become a wild beast, and tear me to pieces."

column2: Thirsty as he was, the brother conquered his desire to drink at her words, and said, "Dear sister, I will wait till we come to a spring." So they wandered farther, but as they approached, she heard in the bubbling spring the words--
column3: Thirsty as he was, the brother conquered his desire to drink at her words, and said, "Dear sister, I will wait till we come to a spring." So they wandered farther, but as they approached, she heard in the bubbling spring the words-

column2: Who drinks of me, a wolf will be.
column3: Who drinks of me, a wolf will be.

column2: Brother, I pray you, do not drink of this brook; you will be changed into a wolf, and devour me.
column3: Brother, I pray you, do not drink of this brook; you will be changed into a wolf, and devour me.

column2: Again the brother denied himself and promised to wait; but he said, "At the next stream I must drink, say what you will, my thirst is so great."
column3: Again the brother denied himself and promised to wait; but he said, "At the next stream I must drink, say what you will, my thirst is so great."

column2: Not far off ran a pretty streamlet, looking clear and bright; but here also in its murmuring waters, the sister heard the words--
column3: Not far off ran a pretty streamlet, looking clear and bright; but here also in its murmuring waters, the sister heard the words-

column2: Who dares to drink of me, Turned to a stag will be.
column3: Who dares to drink of me, Turned to a stag will be.

column2: Dear brother, do not drink, she began; but she was too late, for her brother had already knelt by the stream to drink, and as the first drop of water touched his lips he became a fawn.
column3: Dear brother, do not drink, she began; but she was too late, for her brother had already knelt by the stream to drink, and as the first drop of water touched his lips he became a fawn.

column2: How the little sister wept over the enchanted brother, and the fawn wept also.
column3: How the little sister wept over the enchanted brother, and the fawn wept also.

column2: He did not run away, but stayed close to her; and at last she said, "Stand still, dear fawn; don't fear, I must take care of you, but I will never leave you." So she untied her little golden garter and fastened it round the neck of the fawn; then she gathered some soft green rushes, and braided them into a soft string, which she fastened to the fawn's golden collar, and then led him away into the depths of the forest.
column3: He did not run away, but stayed close to her; and at last she said, "Stand still, dear fawn; don't fear, I must take care of you, but I will never leave you." So she untied her little golden garter and fastened it round the neck of the fawn; then she gathered some soft green rushes, and braided them into a soft string, which she fastened to the fawn's golden collar, and then led him away into the depths of the forest.

column2: After wandering about for some time, they at last found a little deserted hut, and the sister was overjoyed, for she thought it would form a nice shelter for them both.
column3: After wandering about for some time, they at last found a little deserted hut, and the sister was overjoyed, for she thought it would form a nice shelter for them both.

column2: So she led the fawn in, and then went out alone, to gather moss and dried leaves, to make him a soft bed.
column3: So she led the fawn in, and then went out alone, to gather moss and dried leaves, to make him a soft bed.

column2: Every morning she went out to gather dried roots, nuts, and berries, for her own food, and sweet fresh grass for the fawn, which he ate out of her hand, and the poor little animal went out with her, and played about as happy as the day was long.
column3: Every morning she went out to gather dried roots, nuts, and berries, for her own food, and sweet fresh grass for the fawn, which he ate out of her hand, and the poor little animal went out with her, and played about as happy as the day was long.

column2: When evening came, and the poor sister felt tired, she would kneel down and say her prayers, and then lay her delicate head on the fawn's back, which was a soft warm pillow, on which she could sleep peacefully.
column3: When evening came, and the poor sister felt tired, she would kneel down and say her prayers, and then lay her delicate head on the fawn's back, which was a soft warm pillow, on which she could sleep peacefully.

column2: Had this dear brother only kept his own proper form, how happy they would have been together!
column3: Had this dear brother only kept his own proper form, how happy they would have been together!

column2: After they had been alone in the forest for some time, and the little sister had grown a lovely maiden, and the fawn a large stag, a numerous hunting party came to the forest, and amongst them the king of the country.
column3: After they had been alone in the forest for some time, and the little sister had grown a lovely maiden, and the fawn a large stag, a numerous hunting party came to the forest, and amongst them the king of the country.

column2: The sounding horn, the barking of the dogs, the holloa of the huntsmen, resounded through the forest, and were heard by the stag, who became eager to join his companions.
column3: The sounding horn, the barking of the dogs, the holloa of the huntsmen, resounded through the forest, and were heard by the stag, who became eager to join his companions.

column2: Oh dear, he said, "do let me go and see the hunt; I cannot restrain myself." And he begged so hard that at last she reluctantly consented.
column3: Oh dear, he said, "do let me go and see the hunt; I cannot restrain myself." And he begged so hard that at last she reluctantly consented.

column2: But remember, she said, "I must lock the cottage door against those huntsmen, so when you come back in the evening, and knock, I shall not admit you, unless you say, 'Dear little sister let me in.'"
column3: But remember, she said, "I must lock the cottage door against those huntsmen, so when you come back in the evening, and knock, I shall not admit you, unless you say, 'Dear little sister let me in.'"

column2: He bounded off as she spoke, scarcely stopping to listen, for it was so delightful for him to breathe the fresh air and be free again.
column3: He bounded off as she spoke, scarcely stopping to listen, for it was so delightful for him to breathe the fresh air and be free again.

column2: He had not run far when the king's chief hunter caught sight of the beautiful animal, and started off in chase of him; but it was no easy matter to overtake such rapid footsteps.
column3: He had not run far when the king's chief hunter caught sight of the beautiful animal, and started off in chase of him; but it was no easy matter to overtake such rapid footsteps.

column2: Once, when he thought he had him safe, the fawn sprang over the bushes and disappeared.
column3: Once, when he thought he had him safe, the fawn sprang over the bushes and disappeared.

column2: As it was now nearly dark, he ran up to the little cottage, knocked at the door, and cried, "Dear little sister, let me in." The door was instantly opened, and oh, how glad his sister was to see him safely resting on his soft pleasant bed!
column3: As it was now nearly dark, he ran up to the little cottage, knocked at the door, and cried, "Dear little sister, let me in." The door was instantly opened, and oh, how glad his sister was to see him safely resting on his soft pleasant bed!

column2: A few days after this, the huntsmen were again in the forest; and when the fawn heard the holloa, he could not rest in peace, but begged his sister again to let him go.
column3: A few days after this, the huntsmen were again in the forest; and when the fawn heard the holloa, he could not rest in peace, but begged his sister again to let him go.

column2: She opened the door, and said, "I will let you go this time; but pray do not forget to say what I told you, when you return this evening."
column3: She opened the door, and said, "I will let you go this time; but pray do not forget to say what I told you, when you return this evening."

column2: The chief hunter very soon espied the beautiful fawn with the golden collar, pointed it out to the king, and they determined to hunt it.
column3: The chief hunter very soon espied the beautiful fawn with the golden collar, pointed it out to the king, and they determined to hunt it.

column2: They chased him with all their skill till the evening; but he was too light and nimble for them to catch, till a shot wounded him slightly in the foot, so that he was obliged to hide himself in the bushes, and, after the huntsmen were gone, limp slowly home.
column3: They chased him with all their skill till the evening; but he was too light and nimble for them to catch, till a shot wounded him slightly in the foot, so that he was obliged to hide himself in the bushes, and, after the huntsmen were gone, limp slowly home.

column2: One of them, however, determined to follow him at a distance, and discover where he went.
column3: One of them, however, determined to follow him at a distance, and discover where he went.

column2: What was his surprise at seeing him go up to a door and knock, and to hear him say, "Dear little sister, let me in." The door was only opened a little way, and quickly shut; but the huntsman had seen enough to make him full of wonder, when he returned and described to the king what he had seen.
column3: What was his surprise at seeing him go up to a door and knock, and to hear him say, "Dear little sister, let me in." The door was only opened a little way, and quickly shut; but the huntsman had seen enough to make him full of wonder, when he returned and described to the king what he had seen.

column2: We will have one more chase to-morrow, said the king, "and discover this mystery."
column3: We will have one more chase to morrow, said the king, "and discover this mystery."

column2: In the meantime the loving sister was terribly alarmed at finding the stag's foot wounded and bleeding.
column3: In the meantime the loving sister was terribly alarmed at finding the stag's foot wounded and bleeding.

column2: She quickly washed off the blood, and, after bathing the wound, placed healing herbs on it, and said, "Lie down on your bed, dear fawn, and the wound will soon heal, if you rest your foot."
column3: She quickly washed off the blood, and, after bathing the wound, placed healing herbs on it, and said, "Lie down on your bed, dear fawn, and the wound will soon heal, if you rest your foot."

column2: In the morning the wound was so much better that the fawn felt the foot almost as strong as ever, and so, when he again heard the holloa of the hunters, he could not rest.
column3: In the morning the wound was so much better that the fawn felt the foot almost as strong as ever, and so, when he again heard the holloa of the hunters, he could not rest.

column2: Oh, dear sister, I must go once more; it will be easy for me to avoid the hunters now, and my foot feels quite well; they will not hunt me unless they see me running, and I don't mean to do that.
column3: Oh, dear sister, I must go once more; it will be easy for me to avoid the hunters now, and my foot feels quite well; they will not hunt me unless they see me running, and I don't mean to do that.

column2: But his sister wept, and begged him not to go: "If they kill you, dear fawn, I shall be here alone in the forest, forsaken by the whole world."
column3: But his sister wept, and begged him not to go: "If they kill you, dear fawn, I shall be here alone in the forest, forsaken by the whole world."

column2: And I shall die of grief, he said, "if I remain here listening to the hunter's horn."
column3: And I shall die of grief, he said, "if I remain here listening to the hunter's horn."

column2: So at length his sister, with a heavy heart, set him free, and he bounded away joyfully into the forest.
column3: So at length his sister, with a heavy heart, set him free, and he bounded away joyfully into the forest.

column2: As soon as the king caught sight of him, he said to the huntsmen, "Follow that stag about, but don't hurt him." So they hunted him all day, but at the approach of sunset the king said to the hunter who had followed the fawn the day before, "Come and show me the little cottage."
column3: As soon as the king caught sight of him, he said to the huntsmen, "Follow that stag about, but don't hurt him." So they hunted him all day, but at the approach of sunset the king said to the hunter who had followed the fawn the day before, "Come and show me the little cottage."

column2: So they went together, and when the king saw it he sent his companion home, and went on alone so quickly that he arrived there before the fawn; and, going up to the little door, knocked and said softly, "Dear little sister, let me in."
column3: So they went together, and when the king saw it he sent his companion home, and went on alone so quickly that he arrived there before the fawn; and, going up to the little door, knocked and said softly, "Dear little sister, let me in."

column2: As the door opened, the king stepped in, and in great astonishment saw a maiden more beautiful than he had ever seen in his life standing before him.
column3: As the door opened, the king stepped in, and in great astonishment saw a maiden more beautiful than he had ever seen in his life standing before him.

column2: But how frightened she felt to see instead of her dear little fawn a noble gentleman walk in with a gold crown on his head.
column3: But how frightened she felt to see instead of her dear little fawn a noble gentleman walk in with a gold crown on his head.

column2: However, he appeared very friendly, and after a little talk he held out his hand to her, and said, "Wilt thou go with me to my castle and be my dear wife?"
column3: However, he appeared very friendly, and after a little talk he held out his hand to her, and said, "Wilt thou go with me to my castle and be my dear wife?"

column2: Ah yes, replied the maiden, "I would willingly; but I cannot leave my dear fawn: he must go with me wherever I am."
column3: Ah yes, replied the maiden, "I would willingly; but I cannot leave my dear fawn: he must go with me wherever I am."

column2: He shall remain with you as long as you live, replied the king, "and I will never ask you to forsake him."
column3: He shall remain with you as long as you live, replied the king, "and I will never ask you to forsake him."

column2: While they were talking, the fawn came bounding in, looking quite well and happy.
column3: While they were talking, the fawn came bounding in, looking quite well and happy.

column2: Then his sister fastened the string of rushes to his collar, took it in her hand, and led him away from the cottage in the wood to where the king's beautiful horse waited for him.
column3: Then his sister fastened the string of rushes to his collar, took it in her hand, and led him away from the cottage in the wood to where the king's beautiful horse waited for him.

column2: The king placed the maiden before him on his horse and rode away to his castle, the fawn following by their side.
column3: The king placed the maiden before him on his horse and rode away to his castle, the fawn following by their side.

column2: Soon after, their marriage was celebrated with great splendour, and the fawn was taken the greatest care of, and played where he pleased, or roamed about the castle grounds in happiness and safety.
column3: Soon after, their marriage was celebrated with great splendour, and the fawn was taken the greatest care of, and played where he pleased, or roamed about the castle grounds in happiness and safety.

column2: In the meantime the wicked stepmother, who had caused these two young people such misery, supposed that the sister had been devoured by wild beasts, and that the fawn had been hunted to death.
column3: In the meantime the wicked stepmother, who had caused these two young people such misery, supposed that the sister had been devoured by wild beasts, and that the fawn had been hunted to death.

column2: Therefore when she heard of their happiness, such envy and malice arose in her heart that she could find no rest till she had tried to destroy it.
column3: Therefore when she heard of their happiness, such envy and malice arose in her heart that she could find no rest till she had tried to destroy it.

column2: She and her ugly daughter came to the castle when the queen had a little baby, and one of them pretended to be a nurse, and at last got the mother and child into their power.
column3: She and her ugly daughter came to the castle when the queen had a little baby, and one of them pretended to be a nurse, and at last got the mother and child into their power.

column2: They shut the queen up in the bath, and tried to suffocate her, and the old woman put her own ugly daughter in the queen's bed that the king might not know she was away.
column3: They shut the queen up in the bath, and tried to suffocate her, and the old woman put her own ugly daughter in the queen's bed that the king might not know she was away.

column2: She would not, however, let him speak to her, but pretended that she must be kept quite quiet.
column3: She would not, however, let him speak to her, but pretended that she must be kept quite quiet.

column2: The queen escaped from the bath-room, where the wicked old woman had locked her up, but she did not go far, as she wanted to watch over her child and the little fawn.
column3: The queen escaped from the bath room, where the wicked old woman had locked her up, but she did not go far, as she wanted to watch over her child and the little fawn.

column2: For two nights the baby's nurse saw a figure of the queen come into the room and take up her baby and nurse it.
column3: For two nights the baby's nurse saw a figure of the queen come into the room and take up her baby and nurse it.

column2: Then she told the king, and he determined to watch himself.
column3: Then she told the king, and he determined to watch himself.

column2: The old stepmother, who acted as nurse to her ugly daughter, whom she tried to make the king believe was his wife, had said that the queen was too weak to see him, and never left her room.
column3: The old stepmother, who acted as nurse to her ugly daughter, whom she tried to make the king believe was his wife, had said that the queen was too weak to see him, and never left her room.

column2: There cannot be two queens, said the king to himself, "so to-night I will watch in the nursery." As soon as the figure came in and took up her baby, he saw it was his real wife, and caught her in his arms, saying, "You are my own beloved wife, as beautiful as ever."
column3: There cannot be two queens, said the king to himself, "so to night I will watch in the nursery." As soon as the figure came in and took up her baby, he saw it was his real wife, and caught her in his arms, saying, "You are my own beloved wife, as beautiful as ever."

column2: The wicked witch had thrown her into a trance, hoping she would die, and that the king would then marry her daughter; but on the king speaking to her, the spell was broken.
column3: The wicked witch had thrown her into a trance, hoping she would die, and that the king would then marry her daughter; but on the king speaking to her, the spell was broken.

column2: The queen told the king how cruelly she had been treated by her stepmother, and on hearing this he became very angry, and had the witch and her daughter brought to justice.
column3: The queen told the king how cruelly she had been treated by her stepmother, and on hearing this he became very angry, and had the witch and her daughter brought to justice.

column2: They were both sentenced to die--the daughter to be devoured by wild beasts, and the mother to be burnt alive.
column3: They were both sentenced to die-the daughter to be devoured by wild beasts, and the mother to be burnt alive.

column2: No sooner, however, was she reduced to ashes than the charm which held the queen's brother in the form of a stag was broken; he recovered his own natural shape, and appeared before them a tall, handsome young man.
column3: No sooner, however, was she reduced to ashes than the charm which held the queen's brother in the form of a stag was broken; he recovered his own natural shape, and appeared before them a tall, handsome young man.

column2: After this, the brother and sister lived happily and peacefully for the rest of their lives.
column3: After this, the brother and sister lived happily and peacefully for the rest of their lives.

column2: CHAPTER IV
column3: CHAPTER four

column2: HANSEL AND GRETHEL
column3: HANSEL AND GRETHEL

column2: Near the borders of a large forest dwelt in olden times a poor wood-cutter, who had two children--a boy named Hansel, and his sister, Grethel.
column3: Near the borders of a large forest dwelt in olden times a poor wood cutter, who had two children-a boy named Hansel, and his sister, Grethel.

column2: They had very little to live upon, and once when there was a dreadful season of scarcity in the land, the poor wood-cutter could not earn sufficient to supply their daily food.
column3: They had very little to live upon, and once when there was a dreadful season of scarcity in the land, the poor wood cutter could not earn sufficient to supply their daily food.
